en: The Champion of the Weather
zh: 天气寒暄冠军

en: by O. Henry
zh: 作者：欧·亨利

en: If you should speak of the Kiowa Reservation to the average New Yorker he probably wouldn’t know whether you were referring to a new political dodge at Albany or a leitmotif from “Parsifal.”
zh: 要是你跟普通的纽约人说起基奥瓦保留地，他或许不知道你指的是奥尔巴尼的一个新的政治诡计呢，还是《帕西法尔》里的一个主题。
column3: 译者注：Parsifal（帕西法尔），中世纪传奇中的人物，圆桌骑士之一，德国作曲家瓦格纳根据他的故事编写了歌剧《帕西法尔》。

en: But out in the Kiowa Reservation advices have been received concerning the existence of New York.
zh: 但是，基奥瓦保留地那里的人却得到了与纽约人相处的忠告。

en: A party of us were on a hunting trip in the Reservation.
zh: 我们一行人在保留地打猎旅行。

en: Bud Kingsbury, our guide, philosopher, and friend, was broiling antelope steaks in camp one night.
zh: 一天晚上，我们的向导、哲学家和朋友巴德·金斯伯里在营地里烤羚羊肉排。

en: One of the party, a pinkish-haired young man in a correct hunting costume, sauntered over to the fire to light a cigarette, and remarked carelessly to Bud:
zh: 同行的人中一个穿着正规猎装，长着淡红色头发的小伙子漫步到篝火旁，点了一支烟，漫不经心地对巴德说：

en: “Nice night!”
zh: “今晚天气不错！”

en: “Why, yes,” said Bud, “as nice as any night could be that ain’t received the Broadway stamp of approval.”
zh: “啊，是啊，”巴德回应道，“像纽约不需要百老汇批准的任何一晚一样美好。”

en: Now, the young man was from New York, but the rest of us wondered how Bud guessed it.
zh: 这小伙子的确是纽约人，只是我们纳闷巴德怎么会猜到的。

en: So, when the steaks were done, we besought him to lay bare his system of ratiocination.
zh: 羚羊肉排烤好后，我们就恳求他说说他的推理方法。

en: And as Bud was something of a Territorial talking machine he made oration as follows:
zh: 巴德算得上是准州地区的话匣子，他讲了如下一番话：

en: “How did I know he was from New York?
zh: “我怎么知道他是纽约人？

en: Well, I figured it out as soon as he sprung them two words on me.
zh: 其实，他一开口跟我搭讪，我就知道了。

en: I was in New York myself a couple of years ago, and I noticed some of the earmarks and hoof tracks of the Rancho Manhattan.”
zh: 几年前我在纽约呆过，我能辨认出曼哈顿牧场出来牲畜的耳记和蹄印。”

en: “Found New York rather different from the Panhandle, didn’t you, Bud?” asked one of the hunters.
zh: 一个猎人问道：“巴德，你是不是发现纽约和锅柄地带大不一样？”

en: “Can’t say that I did,” answered Bud; “anyways, not more than some.
zh: “不能说完全了解，”巴德回答说，“多少有些了解。

en: The main trail in that town which they call Broadway is plenty travelled, but they’re about the same brand of bipeds that tramp around in Cheyenne and Amarillo, At first I was sort of rattled by the crowds, but I soon says to myself, ‘Here, now, Bud; they’re just plain folks like you and Geronimo and Grover Cleveland and the Watson boys, so don’t get all flustered up with consternation under your saddle blanket,’ and then I feels calm and peaceful, like I was back in the Nation again at a ghost dance or a green corn pow-wow.
zh: 那条他们称为百老汇的大街上，来往行人很多，不过和夏延和阿马里洛的两足动物的种类相差无几。一开始，熙熙攘攘的人头攒动使我有些慌张，但是后来我对自己说：‘嘿，巴德，他们无非是些普通人，跟你自己、杰罗尼莫、格罗弗·克利夫兰和沃森兄弟一样，没必要惊慌失措。’这样一来，我踏实多了，仿佛又回到了保留地，正在参加印第安人的鬼神舞和庆祝玉米丰收的狂欢活动。”

en: “I’d been saving up for a year to give this New York a whirl.
zh: “那时，我攒了一年钱，准备到纽约来一个短暂旅行。

en: I knew a man named Summers that lived there, but I couldn’t find him; so I played a lone hand at enjoying the intoxicating pleasures of the corn-fed metropolis.
zh: 我有一个叫萨默斯的朋友住在那里，可是我没能找到他，所以我只好独自享受那个喧嚣大都会的醉人的快乐。

en: “For a while I was so frivolous and locoed by the electric lights and the noises of the phonographs and the second-story railroads that I forgot one of the crying needs of my Western system of natural requirements.
zh: “五光十色的电灯、留声机里传出的音乐和高架铁路的轰响一度让我烦躁到发疯，都忘了作为西部人本性中的一个迫切需要。

en: I never was no hand to deny myself the pleasures of sociable vocal intercourse with friends and strangers.
zh: 我一向喜欢和朋友和陌生人进行语言交流。

en: Out in the Territories when I meet a man I never saw before, inside of nine minutes I know his income, religion, size of collar, and his wife’s temper, and how much he pays for clothes, alimony, and chewing tobacco.
zh: 如果我在准州地区遇上一个从未见过面的人，九分钟之内，我就可以知道他的收入、宗教信仰、衣领尺寸、他妻子的脾气，和他在添置衣服、维持生计跟买嚼烟方面的花费有多少。

en: It’s a gift with me not to be penurious with my conversation.
zh: 不吝啬与对方的谈话是我的一个天赋。

en: “But this here New York was inaugurated on the idea of abstemiousness in regard to the parts of speech.
zh: “但是纽约这里似乎崇尚言简意赅的原则。

en: At the end of three weeks nobody in the city had fired even a blank syllable in my direction except the waiter in the grub emporium where I fed.
zh: 我呆了将近三个星期，除了我就餐的那家饭馆的侍者之外，没有其他人跟我说过话。

en: And as his outpourings of syntax wasn’t nothing but plagiarisms from the bill of fare, he never satisfied my yearnings, which was to have somebody hit.
zh: 那侍者说的话也都是照搬菜单，根本无法满足我想要找人一吐为快的欲望。

en: If I stood next to a man at a bar he’d edge off and give a Baldwin-Ziegler look as if he suspected me of having the North Pole concealed on my person.
zh: 假使我在酒吧前一站，旁边的人就会挪开一点儿，一副避之不及的样子，好像我身上藏着整个北极似的。

en: I began to wish that I’d gone to Abilene or Waco for my paseado; for the mayor of them places will drink with you, and the first citizen you meet will tell you his middle name and ask you to take a chance in a raffle for a music box.
zh: 我倒希望当初是去阿比林或者韦科玩，因为那些地方的市长都会陪你喝酒，你遇到的第一个居民会把他的中间的名字告诉你，还会让你抽奖碰碰运气，没准能得到一个音乐盒。

en: “Well, one day when I was particular hankering for to be gregarious with something more loquacious than a lamp post, a fellow in a caffy says to me, says he:
zh: “有一天，我特别想找一个比电线杆健谈的对象说说话。酒馆里一个伙计招呼我说：

en: “‘Nice day!’
zh: “‘天气不错！’

en: “He was a kind of a manager of the place, and I reckon he’d seen me in there a good many times.
zh: “那人应该是酒馆的经理，我估计他见过我这个熟客多次。

en: He had a face like a fish and an eye like Judas, but I got up and put one arm around his neck.
zh: 他长了一张鱼脸和一双犹大的眼睛，但我马上起身，搂住他的脖子。

en: “‘Pardner,’ I says, ‘sure it’s a nice day.
zh: “‘嘿，伙计，’我说，‘天气确实不赖。

en: You’re the first gentleman in all New York to observe that the intricacies of human speech might not be altogether wasted on William Kingsbury.
zh: 你是全纽约第一个注意到人类错综复杂的语言在威廉·金斯伯里身上不会白白浪费的人。

en: But don’t you think,’ says I, ‘that ’twas a little cool early in the morning; and ain’t there a feeling of rain in the air to-night?
zh: 但是，你觉不觉得，’我继续说道，‘清晨稍微有些凉，今晚的空气里有点儿要下雨的意思？

en: But along about noon it sure was gallupsious weather.
zh: 不过中午时候的天气确实好极了。

en: How’s all up to the house?
zh: 你家里一切平安吗？

en: You doing right well with the caffy, now?’
zh: 酒馆这阵子买卖如何？’

en: “Well, sir, that galoot just turns his back and walks off stiff, without a word, after all my trying to be agreeable!
zh: “可是，你们看，尽管我使出浑身解数想迎合那傻瓜，他却一句话也没说，转身讪讪地走开了！

en: I didn’t know what to make of it.
zh: 我真搞不懂该怎么办才好。

en: That night I finds a note from Summers, who’d been away from town, giving the address of his camp.
zh: 那天晚上，我收到萨默斯的来信，说是之前到城外野营去了。

en: I goes up to his house and has a good, old-time talk with his folks.
zh: 我便到他家里，同他一家痛快地聊了起来。

en: And I tells Summers about the actions of this coyote in the caffy, and desires interpretation.
zh: 我把酒馆里那个野蛮人的事告诉萨默斯，希望他给我解释一下。

en: “‘Oh,’ says Summers, ‘he wasn’t intending to strike up a conversation with you.
zh: “‘哦，’萨默斯说，‘他并不想跟你攀谈。

en: That’s just the New York style.
zh: 那只是纽约式的寒暄。

en: He’d seen you was a regular customer and he spoke a word or two just to show you he appreciated your custom.
zh: 他知道你是常客，说一两句话对你光顾他的生意表示感谢。

en: You oughtn’t to have followed it up.
zh: 你当时不必接他的话。

en: That’s about as far as we care to go with a stranger.
zh: 就当是对待陌生人一样。

en: A word or so about the weather may be ventured, but we don’t generally make it the basis of an acquaintance.’
zh: 可以说一两句关于天气的话，但我们不把那当作交朋友的基础。’

en: “‘Billy,’ says I, ‘the weather and its ramifications is a solemn subject with me.
zh: “‘比利，’我说，‘对我来说，天气和与天气有关的都是严肃的话题。

en: Meteorology is one of my sore points.
zh: 气象学是我的痛处之一。

en: No man can open up the question of temperature or humidity or the glad sunshine with me, and then turn tail on it without its leading to a falling barometer.
zh: 无论谁跟我提起温度、湿度或者灿烂的阳光，不继续说气压下降，扭头就走，那可不行。

en: I’m going down to see that man again and give him a lesson in the art of continuous conversation.
zh: 我会再去找那个人，给他上一课，讲讲使谈话继续下去的艺术。

en: You say New York etiquette allows him two words and no answer.
zh: 你说纽约规矩允许他甩出一两句话不必等回应。

en: Well, he’s going to turn himself into a weather bureau and finish what he begun with me, besides indulging in neighbourly remarks on other subjects.’
zh: 哼，对我可不行。我要把他变成气象局，非让他把先挑起的话题说完不可，并且要接着尽情聊聊其他有关的话题。’

en: “Summers talked agin it, but I was irritated some and I went on the street car back to that caffy.
zh: “萨默斯不赞同我的做法，但我心里头有气，就乘上电车回到了那家酒馆。

en: “The same fellow was there yet, walking round in a sort of back corral where there was tables and chairs.
zh: “那个人还在那个有桌椅的畜栏似的地方走来走去。

en: A few people was sitting around having drinks and sneering at one another.
zh: 房间里散坐着一些喝酒的顾客，他们正在互相抬杠。

en: “I called that man to one side and herded him into a corner.
zh: “我把那人叫到一边，带他到一个角落。

en: I unbuttoned enough to show him a thirty-eight I carried stuck under my vest.
zh: 我解开衣扣，露出插在坎肩里面的三八口径手枪。

en: “‘Pardner,’ I says, ‘a brief space ago I was in here and you seized the opportunity to say it was a nice day.
zh: “‘伙计，’我说，‘不久前，我在这里时，你乘机跟我说天气不错。

en: When I attempted to corroborate your weather signal, you turned your back and walked off.
zh: 我正要证实你的天气预报，你却转身走开了。

en: Now,’ says I, ‘you frog-hearted, language-shy, stiff-necked cross between a Spitzbergen sea cook and a muzzled oyster, you resume where you left off in your discourse on the weather.’
zh: 你听好，’我接着说，‘你这个长着青蛙心、寡言少语、倔头倔脑的新水手和闭嘴牡蛎的杂交品种，现在把你没说完的天气话题接着说完。’

en: “The fellow looks at me and tries to grin, but he sees I don’t and he comes around serious.
zh: “那家伙瞅着我，咧嘴想笑，但看到我并没有笑意，便也收起笑容，严肃起来。

en: “‘Well,’ says he, eyeing the handle of my gun, ‘it was rather a nice day; some warmish, though.’
zh: “‘嗯，’他瞥着我的枪把说，‘天气相当好，就是有些热。’

en: “‘Particulars, you mealy-mouthed snoozer,’ I says—‘let’s have the specifications—expatiate—fill in the outlines.
zh: “‘说详细些，你这个油嘴滑舌的懒鬼，’我说，‘我们要听些具体情况——扩展一下——补充细节。

en: When you start anything with me in short-hand it’s bound to turn out a storm signal.’
zh: 你要是拿简报糊弄我，我保证那会变成暴风雨警报。’

en: “‘Looked like rain yesterday,’ says the man, ‘but it cleared off fine in the forenoon.
zh: “‘昨天有下雨的迹象，’他说，‘但午前云开日出。

en: I hear the farmers are needing rain right badly up-State.’
zh: 我听说，北部农民迫切盼望下雨。’

en: “‘That’s the kind of a canter,’ says I.
zh: “‘你这只是在慢跑，’我说，

en: ‘Shake the New York dust off your hoofs and be a real agreeable kind of a centaur.
zh: ‘甩掉你蹄子上的纽约尘土，像个真正的半人半马兽一样跑利索些。

en: You broke the ice, you know, and we’re getting better acquainted every minute.
zh: 你知道的，你已经打破了沉闷，我们越来越熟了。

en: Seems to me I asked you about your family?’
zh: 我当时好像还问过你的家人来着？’

en: “‘They’re all well, thanks,’ says he.
zh: “‘他们都好，谢谢，’他说，

en: ‘We—we have a new piano.’
zh: ‘我们——我们新买了一架钢琴。’

en: “‘Now you’re coming it,’ I says.
zh: “‘现在你说到点子上了，’我说，

en: ‘This cold reserve is breaking up at last.
zh: ‘沉默的坚冰终于被打破了。

en: That little touch about the piano almost makes us brothers.
zh: 你一说到钢琴，我们就像兄弟那样亲密了。

en: What’s the youngest kid’s name?’ I asks him.
zh: 你家里最小的孩子叫什么？’我继续问。

en: “‘Thomas,’ says he.
zh: “‘托马斯，’他说，

en: ‘He’s just getting well from the measles.’
zh: ‘他刚得过麻疹，正在康复。’

en: “‘I feel like I’d known you always,’ says I.
zh: “‘我觉得我们一见如故，’我说，

en: ‘Now there was just one more—are you doing right well with the caffy, now?’
zh: ‘现在就剩一个问题了——酒馆生意如何？’

en: “‘Pretty well,’ he says.
zh: “‘相当不错，’他答道，

en: ‘I’m putting away a little money.’
zh: ‘现在可以攒些钱了。’

en: “‘Glad to hear it,’ says I.
zh: “‘我听了很高兴，’我说，

en: ‘Now go back to your work and get civilized.
zh: ‘现在回去工作吧，以后文明点儿。

en: Keep your hands off the weather unless you’re ready to follow it up in a personal manner, It’s a subject that naturally belongs to sociability and the forming of new ties, and I hate to see it handed out in small change in a town like this.’
zh: 如果不准备以个人的方式把天气谈个透，就别碰天气这个话题。这个话题属于交际和结识新朋友的范畴，我不喜欢在这样的大城市里看到这个话题变成简单的寒暄。’

en: “So the next day I rolls up my blankets and hits the trail away from New York City.”
zh: “第二天，我卷起毯子，离开了纽约。”

en: For many minutes after Bud ceased talking we lingered around the fire, and then all hands began to disperse for bed.
zh: 巴德说完后，我们围在火堆旁又呆了一会儿，最后大家分散准备睡觉。

en: As I was unrolling my bedding I heard the pinkish-haired young man saying to Bud, with something like anxiety in his voice:
zh: 我摊开被褥时，听到那个淡红色头发的小伙子忧心忡忡地对巴德说：

en: “As I say, Mr. Kingsbury, there is something really beautiful about this night.
zh: “金斯伯里先生，正如我刚才所说，今晚天气确实不坏。

en: The delightful breeze and the bright stars and the clear air unite in making it wonderfully attractive.”
zh: 微风徐徐、星光灿烂、空气清新，这一切都使今晚格外迷人。”

en: “Yes,” said Bud, “it’s a nice night.”
zh: “没错，”巴德说，“今晚天气不错。”
